question: A lower limit of a Control Area shall be established at a height above the ground level or water of not less than:

choices.choice: 150 metres
200 metres
300 metres

explanation:
Control areas including, inter alia, airways and terminal control areas shall be delineated so as to encompass sufficient airspace to contain the flight paths of those IFR flights or portions thereof to which it is desired to provide the applicable parts of the air traffic control service, taking into account the capabilities of the navigation aids normally used in that area.
A lower limit of a control area shall be established at a height above the ground or water of not less than 200 m (700 ft).
subject: Regulations

question: The Approach Control Service is an air traffic control service

choices.choice: provided for the arriving and departing controlled flights
for IFR flights arriving and departing
provided for IFR traffic within a Control Zone

explanation:
• Area Control Service:
    • This service is provided for controlled flights within Control Areas (CTAs) and while en route within Flight Information Regions (FIRs) and Upper Information Regions (UIRs).
    • It ensures safe and efficient navigation of aircraft during the cruise phase, as well as transitions between sectors.
  • Approach Control Service:
    • This service manages the controlled flights associated with arrival and departure at airports.
    • It is typically provided within Control Zones (CTRs) and is responsible for sequencing, separation, and guidance during the critical phases of approach and initial departure from the airport vicinity.
  • Aerodrome Control Service:
    • This service is responsible for providing ATC to aerodrome traffic at controlled aerodromes.
    • It ensures safe operations on the ground (runways, taxiways) and in the immediate airspace around the aerodrome.
subject: Regulations

question: The units providing Air Traffic Services are:

choices.choice: Area control Center- Advisory Center- Flight information Center- Approach Control Office and Tower
Area Control Center- Flight Information Center- Approach Control Office- Aerodrome Control Tower and Air Traffic Services reporting office
Area Control Center- Approach Control Office and Aerodrome Control Tower only.

explanation:
Air Traffic Service (ATS)

Definition

A generic term meaning variously, flight information service, alerting service, air traffic advisory service, air traffic control service (area control service, approach control service or aerodrome control service).
subject: Regulations

question: Air traffic control service is provided for purpose of:

choices.choice: Avoiding collisions between all aircraft and maintaining and orderly flow of air traffic
Preventing collisions between aircraft, between aircraft and obstacles on the manoeuvring area and expediting and maintaining an orderly flow of air traffic
Preventing collisions between controlled air traffic and expediting and maintaining an orderly flow of air traffic

explanation:
Objectives. The objectives of an ATS are to:
• Prevent collisions between aircraft;
• Prevent collisions between aircraft on the manoeuvring area and obstructions thereon;
• Expedite and maintain an orderly flow of air traffic;
• Provide advice and information useful for the safe and efficient conduct of flights;
• Notify appropriate organizations regarding aircraft in need of SAR aid, and assist such
organizations as required.
subject: Regulations

question: To perform a VFR flight in airspace classification E

choices.choice: a clearance and/or two-way radio communication is required
a clearance is required
two-way radio communication is not required

subject: Regulations

question: Which statements is correct?

choices.choice: The lower limit of an UIR may coincide with an IFR cruising level
The lower limit of a TMA shall be established at a height of at least 700ft AGL
The upper limit of a CTR shall be established at a height of at least 3000ft AMSL

explanation:
A flight information region is limited by an upper flight information region, the lower limit specified for the upper flight information region shall constitute the upper vertical limit of the flight information region and shall coincide with a VFR cruising level

The lower limit of a control area (CTA or TMA) can be expressed as a height, pressure altitude or flight level but cannot be less than 200 m (700 ft) above the ground. The lower limit does not have to be uniform over the whole control area.

ICAO recommends for the lower level to coincide with a VFR cruising level if the lower-level limit of a control area is above 900 m (3000 feet) MSL (mean sea level), and the VFR cruising level to not have to be lowered to less than 200 m (700 feet) due to atmospheric conditions. The upper limit should be established when either air traffic control service will not be provided above that level, or there is another (upper) control area above this control area.
subject: Regulations

question: What is the speed limit (IAS) in an airspace class E?

choices.choice: 250kt VFR and IFR, all levels
250kt for IFR and VFR up to FL 100
250 kt only for IFR up to FL 100

subject: Regulations

question: The speed limitation for IFR flights inside ATS airspace classified as C, when flying below 3050m (1000ft)AMSL, is:

choices.choice: 250kt IAS
Not applicable
250kt TAS

subject: Regulations

question: RCP 10 means:

choices.choice: 10 is the number of seconds it takes for an instruction to travel from the ground to aircraft and acknowledgment back to the ground.
10 is the maximum number of minutes it takes for an instruction to be executed by an aircraft.
Aircraft must communicate with ATC every 10 minutes.

explanation:
ICAO (International Civil Aviation Organization) defines Required Communication Performance (RCP) in Annex 10, Volume III related to communications systems.

In particular, RCP 10 means that the total time required for a message to be sent from the ground to the aircraft, acknowledged by the aircraft, and received back on the ground should not exceed 10 seconds.
subject: Regulations

question: An ATS airspace where IFR and VFR flights are permitted, all flights are subject to air traffic control service and are separated from each other is classified as

choices.choice: Airspace C
Airspace B
Airspace D

subject: Regulations

question: The sped limitation for both IFR flights and VFR flights inside ATS airspace classified as B, when flying below 3050m (10000ft) AMLS, is:

choices.choice: 260kt IAS
Not applicable
250kt IAS

subject: Regulations

question: Air traffic services unit clocks and other time recording devices shall be checked as necessary to ensure correct time within plus or minus

choices.choice: 1 minute of UTC at all times
15 seconds of UTC at all times
30 seconds of UTC at all times

explanation:
The requirement that Air Traffic Services (ATS) unit clocks and time recording devices must be kept within plus or minus 30 seconds of UTC is outlined in ICAO Annex 15 and PANS-ATM (ICAO Doc 4444).

This ensures accuracy in time-sensitive aviation operations, particularly for coordination between ATC units and pilots, filing flight plans, and tracking aircraft movements.
subject: Regulations

question: The following airspace fails under Kolkata FIR?

choices.choice: VED
VEB
VOR

explanation: An airspace of defined dimensions within which activities dangerous to the flight of aircraft exist at the specified times. Such times are notified byNOTAM’s.The effect of the notification of the Danger Area is to caution aircraft operators/pilots that it is necessary for them to avoid it for the safety of the aircraft when the areas are active. This type of area is indicated by the letter (D) preceded by two letter designator of the FIR and followed by a number e.g. VE(D)-72, indicates Danger Area No. 72 in Calcutta FIR.
subject: Regulations

question: The VMC minima for a VFR flight inside and ATS airspace classified as B, is:

choices.choice: 8km visibility when at or above 3050m (10000ft) AMSL and clear of clouds
8km visibility when at or above 3050m (10000ft) AMSL, and 1500m horizontal and 300m vertical from clouds
5NM visibility when below 3050m (10000ft) AMSL, 1500m horizontal and 300m vertical from cloud

question: A VFR flight when flying inside and ATS airspace classified as B has to maintain the following minima of flight visibility and distance from clouds

choices.choice: 5km visibility, 1500m horizontal and 300m vertical from clouds
8km below 3050m (10000ft) AMSL, 1500m horizontal and 300m vertical from clouds
5km below 3050m (10000ft) AMSL and clear of clouds

subject: Regulations

question: An ATS airspace where IFR and VER flights are permitted, all flights are subject to air traffic control service and IFR flights are separated from other IFR flights and receive traffic information in respect of other VFR flights, is classified as:

choices.choice: Airspace B
Airspace E
Airspace C

question: Which condition is requested so that an aerodrome may be considered controlled?

choices.choice: The aerodrome shall be provided with a Control Tower
The aerodrome shall be located within a Control Zone (CTR) and provided with a Control Tower
The aerodrome shall be located within a Control Zone

explanation:
Controlled Aerodromes. Those aerodromes where it is determined that air traffic control service will be provided to aerodrome traffic shall be designated as controlled aerodromes.

Aerodrome Control Service: by an aerodrome control tower.
subject: Regulations

question: An ATS airspace where IFR and VFR flights are permitted, and all flights are subject to air traffic control service. IFR flights are separated from other IFR flights and receive traffic information in respect of VFR flights. VER flights receive traffic information in respect of all other flights, is classified as:

choices.choice: Airspace B
Airspace D
Airspace A

subject: Regulations

question: An ATS airspace where IFR and VFR flights are permitted are subject to Air Traffic Control Service and are separated from other IFR flights. All flights receive traffic information as far as practical, is classified as

choices.choice: Airspace D
Airspace A
Airspace E

subject: Regulations

question: An ATS airspace where IFR and VFR flights are permitted, all participating IFR flights receive an air traffic advisory service and all flights receive flight information service if requested, is classified

choices.choice: Airspace F
Airspace E
Airspace D

subject: Regulations

question: Which statement regarding approach control service is correct?

choices.choice: Approach control have to advise the aircraft operators about substantial delays in departure in any event when they are expected to exceed 45 minutes
During a visual approach an aircraft is maintaining its own separation
If it is anticipated that an aircraft has to hold for 30 minutes or more, an Expected Approach Time will be transmitted by the most expeditious means to the aircraft

explanation:
Expected Approach Time (EAT). When an aircraft enters a stack the controlling ATCO
will pass an EAT which must be acknowledged by the pilot. This will be the time that the pilot can expect to commence the instrument approach. Initially the EAT will not be less than 30 minutes after the time of entry. If it is expected that the aircraft will not be held for more than 20 minutes, the pilot will be informed “no delay expected”.

Separation. Separation shall be provided between an aircraft cleared to execute a visual
approach and other arriving and departing aircraft. For successive visual approaches, radar
or non-radar separation shall be maintained until the pilot of a succeeding aircraft reports
having the preceding aircraft in sight. The aircraft shall be instructed to follow and maintain separation from the preceding aircraft.

Delays. In order to avoid excessive holding at the destination, aircraft may be held
at the departure aerodrome prior to take-off. ATC is required to advise operators (or their
nominated representative) of substantial delays and in any case where the delay is expected to exceed 30 minutes.
subject: Regulations

question: Which statement regarding aerodrome control service is correct?

choices.choice: An aircraft entering the traffic circuit without permission of ATC, will be cleared to land if this is desirable
Suspension of VFR operations can not be initiated by the aerodrome controller
ATC permission is required for entering the apron with a vehicle

explanation:
The movement of aeroplanes and vehicular traffic on the apron may be delegated to an Apron Management Service. In this case, ATC would commence once the aircraft moves onto the taxi-way and will cease when the pilot takes instructions from a marshaller.

All VFR operations on and in the vicinity of a TWR controller may be suspended by any controller in charge of the TWR controller. The VFR operations should be suspended when weather conditions are below visual meteorological conditions (VMC) minima.
subject: Regulations

question: In ATS route designator UA1Y what does U mean:

choices.choice: Upper
Undirectional
Uniform

explanation:
Route Designators. Airways are given a ‘designator’ which defines the type of airway,
gives it a unique number and provides additional information about the type of route. The
specific route designator indicates what type of route is defined and, in addition, a unique
number (1 – 999).
subject: Regulations

question: Special VFR flights may be authorized to operate locally within a control zone when the ground visibility is not less than 1500 metres, even when the aircraft is not equipped with a functioning radio receiver within class:

choices.choice: D airspace
D and E airspace
E airspace

subject: Regulations

question: Flight information service shall be provided to all aircrafts which are likely to be affected by the information and which are:

choices.choice: Provided with the air traffic control services and otherwise known to the relevant air traffic service units
Known to the relevant air traffic services units by a filed flightplan
Provided with air traffic control services, only

explanation:
A flight information service (FIS) is a form of air traffic service which is available to any aircraft within a flight information region (FIR), as agreed internationally by ICAO.

It is defined as information pertinent to the safe and efficient conduct of flight, and includes information on other potentially conflicting traffic, possibly derived from radar, but stopping short of providing positive separation from that traffic.

Flight Information also includes:

  • Meteorological information
  • Information on aerodromes
  • Information on possible hazards to flight

FIS shall be provided to all aircraft which are provided with any air traffic control (ATC) service or are otherwise known to air traffic service units. All air traffic service units will provide an FIS to any aircraft, in addition to their other tasks.
subject: Regulations

question: Alerting service shall be provided:

choices.choice: For all controlled flight, to any aircraft known or believed to be subject of unlawful interference, and in so far as practicable to all aircraft having filed a flight plan or otherwise known to the ATS
For all aircraft provided with air traffic control services, only
To any aircraft known or believed to be subject of unlawful interference, only

explanation:
The Alerting Service provided by Air Traffic Services (ATS) units acts as a vital link between aircraft in distress and the agencies capable of providing assistance. It is applicable under the following conditions:

  1. All aircraft provided with ATC (Air Traffic Control) services.
  2. As far as practicable, for all aircraft that have filed a flight plan (FP) or are otherwise known to ATC.
  3. Any aircraft known or believed to be subject to unlawful interference
subject: Regulations

question: The speed limitation for IFR flights inside ATS airspace classified as E, when flying below 3050m (10000ft) AMSL, is:

choices.choice: 250kt TAS
250kt IAS
Not applicable

subject: Regulations

question: Air Traffic Service unit means:

choices.choice: Air Traffic Control units and Air Services reporting offices
Flight Information Centers and Air Services reporting offices
Air Traffic Control units, Flight Information Centers or Air services reporting offices

explanation:
An Air Traffic Service (ATS) unit refers to any of the following:

  • Air Traffic Control (ATC) units (such as area control centers, approach control units, or aerodrome control towers).
  • Flight Information Centers (FIC), which provide information services to ensure the safety and efficiency of air navigation.
  • Air Services reporting offices, where flight plans are filed and relevant information is communicated to air traffic services.
subject: Regulations

question: A controlled airspace extending upwards from a specified limit above the earth is:

choices.choice: Advisory airspace
Control area
Flight Information Region

explanation:
Control Area:

Controlled airspace extending upwards from a specified limit above the earth. Control Areas are situated above the Aerodrome Traffic Zone (ATZ) and afford protection over a
larger area to a specified upper limit.
subject: Regulations

question: Tirupati aerodrome designator is?

choices.choice: VATP
VOTP
VITP

explanation:
Sri Venkateswara International Airport (IATA: TIR, ICAO: VOTP)

IATA stands for International Air Transport Association.
subject: Regulations

question: Aerodrome traffic is:

choices.choice: All traffic on the manoeuvring area and flying in the vicinity of an aerodrome
All traffic in the aerodrome circuit
All traffic on the manoeuvring area

explanation:
Aerodrome Traffic. All traffic on the maneuvering area of an aerodrome and all aircraft flying in the vicinity of an aerodrome.

Aerodrome Traffic Zone. Airspace of defined dimensions established around an aerodrome for the protection of aerodrome traffic.
subject: Regulations

question: Which of the following Annexes to the Chicago convention contains international standards and recommended practices for air traffic services (ATS)?

choices.choice: Annex 6
Annex 14
Annex 11

subject: Regulations

question: An information issued by a meteorological watch office concerning the occurence or expected occurence of specified en-route weather phenomena which may affect the safety of low-level aircraft operations and which was not already included in the forecast issued for low level flights in the flight information region concerned or sub-area thereof is

choices.choice: An En-Route Met Report
A NOTAM
An AIRMET information

explanation: An AIRMET, or Airmen’s Meteorological Information, is a concise description of weather phenomena that are occurring or may occur (forecast) along an air route that may affect aircraft safety. Compared to SIGMETs, AIRMETs cover less severe weather: moderate turbulence and icing, sustained surface winds of 30 knots or more, or widespread restricted visibility.
subject: Regulations

question: Regarding Aerodrome Flight information (AFIS):

choices.choice: Its purpose is to supply ATC services but it is not a state organisation
It can only supply limited services to the users and under no circumstances may it supply ATC services
It has the same privileges and prerogatives as an ATC organisation but its activity is neither continuous nor regular

explanation: AFIS units are tasked with the provision of FIS and Alerting service within their jurisdictional airspace, without being considered an ATC unit; aerodromes identified as “AFIS aerodromes” maintain the status of “non-controlled” aerodromes.
subject: Regulations

question: Air Traffic Control service shall be provided to:

choices.choice: All IFR flights in class A, B, C, D, E and F airspaces.
All VFR flights in class B, C, D and E airspaces.
To all aerodrome traffic at controlled aerodromes.

explanation:
Air Traffic Control (ATC) is the service provided to controlled flights
inside controlled airspace or to aerodrome traffic at controlled aerodromes. ATC is always
provided to IFR traffic inside CAS whereas ATC is only provided to VFR flights in classes B, C and D. Additionally, all SVFR flights are provided with ATC.
subject: Regulations

question: Flight Information Region (FIR) is an airspace within which the following services are provided:

choices.choice: Flight Information Service and Alerting Service
Flight Information Service and Advisory Service
Flight Information Service, Alerting Service and Advisory Service

explanation:
Flight Information Service and Alerting Service.

In a Flight Information Region (FIR), the following services are provided:

  • Flight Information Service (FIS): This includes information about weather, air traffic conditions, and other operational data that supports safe flight.
  • Alerting Service: This service is responsible for alerting appropriate organizations regarding aircraft that need assistance, such as emergencies or search-and-rescue operations.
subject: Regulations

question: Control Area (CTA) is defined as follows:

choices.choice: A controlled airpsace extending upwards from a specified limit above the earth
A controlled airspace extending upwards from the surface of the earth to a specified limit
A controlled airspace extending upwards from a height of 900ft above the earth

explanation:
Control Area:

Controlled airspace extending upwards from a specified limit above the earth. Control Areas are situated above the Aerodrome Traffic Zone (ATZ) and afford protection over a
larger area to a specified upper limit.
subject: Regulations

question: Aerodrome local flying area is to be considered, if ATZ is not notified:

choices.choice: With in 5 NM of ARP up to 3000 feet.
With in 25 NM of ARP up to 10,000 feet.
With in 10 NM of ARP up to 5000 feet.

explanation: If an Aerodrome Traffic Zone (ATZ) is not specifically notified, the aerodrome local flying area is generally considered to extend within 5 NM of the Aerodrome Reference Point (ARP) and up to 3000 feet above ground level. This area is often used for local flight operations, such as training, circuits, or light aircraft movements around the aerodrome.
subject: Regulations

question: An air traffic control unit:

choices.choice: May ask an aircraft to temporarily change its callsign for safety reasons when there is a risk of confusion between two or more similar callsigns
May not ask an aircraft to change its callsign after accepting the flight plan
Must not ask an aircraft to change its callsign

explanation:
Call signs may be abbreviated only in the manner shown below (see table above.)

  • Type (a) The first character of the registration and at least the last two characters of the full call sign (the name of the aircraft manufacturer or model may be used in place of the first character);
  • Type (b) The telephony designator of the aircraft operating agency, followed by at least the last two characters of the call sign;
  • Type (c) No abbreviated form.

Most airline call signs belong to type (c) for which there is no abbreviation. Therefore, abbreviations such as “1234” or “Rushair 34” are not permissible. An aircraft is not permitted to change its call sign during flight, except temporarily on the instruction of an air traffic control unit in the interests of safety.
subject: Regulations

question: Required Navigation Performance (RNP) shall be prescribed

choices.choice: By regional air navigation agreements
By states but not on the basis of regional air agreements
By states on the basis of regional air navigation agreements

explanation:
• RNP is a numerical value representing the navigational accuracy required in a specific airspace.
  • It is based on regional air navigation agreements (RANs) and implemented by individual states.
subject: Regulations

question: A Control Zone shall extend laterally to at least:

choices.choice: 10 miles from the centre of the aerodrome or aerodromes concerned in the direction from which approaches maybe made
5 nautical miles from the centre of the aerodrome or aerodromes concerned in the direction from which approaches may be made
20 miles from the centre of the aerodrome of aerodromes concerned in the direction from which approaches may be made

explanation:
• A CTR should be large enough to encompass the airspace necessary to provide air traffic control services for arriving and departing aircraft.
  • Typically, a CTR will extend at least 5 nautical miles (NM) from the Aerodrome Reference Point (ARP) in the direction from which approaches are made.
  • When the CTR is established within a Control Area (CTA), it must extend upwards to the lower limit of the CTA to ensure continuous controlled airspace coverage for aircraft transitioning between different airspace layers.

CTR   Control Zone
subject: Regulations

question: G245ZF is a designator for:

choices.choice: a SID
a STAR
an ATS Route

explanation:
The ATS route designator shall consist of:

– One prefix (optional)
– One letter
– A number
– One additional letter (optional)

 

  • A, B, G, or R: Routes that form part of the regional networks of ATS routes and are not area navigation (RNAV) routes.
  • L, M, N, or P: Routes for area navigation (RNAV) which form part of the regional networks of ATS routes.
  • H, J, V, or W: Routes which do not form part of the regional networks of ATS routes and are not RNAV routes.
  • Q, T, Y, or Z: Routes for area navigation which do not form part of the regional networks of ATS routes.
subject: Regulations

question: An ATS airspace where IFR and VFR are permitted and receive flight information service if requested, is classified as

choices.choice: Airspace G
Airspace E
Airspace C

subject: Regulations

question: Concerning to RNP (Required Navigation Performance) types, the Indication RNP 4, represents a navigation accuracy of

choices.choice: Plus or minus 4 NM on a 95% containment basis
Plus or minus 4 NM on a 98% containment basis
Plus or minus 4 NM on a 90% containment basis

explanation:
The RNP standard is based on a 95% containment factor, meaning an aircraft will remain within the required accuracy at least 95% of the time while operating in that airspace.

RNP 4 implies that an aircraft’s navigation system must be accurate enough to keep the aircraft within 4 nautical miles of its intended or plotted position for 95% of the time while operating within the airspace concerned.

RNP 4: Applicable to oceanic and remote continental navigation.
subject: Regulations

question: Area Control Centers issue clearances for the purpose of:

choices.choice: Achieving separation between IFR flights
Achieving separation between controlled flights
Providing flight information Service

explanation:
Achieving separation between controlled flights.

This includes both IFR (Instrument Flight Rules) flights and VFR (Visual Flight Rules) flights when the latter are operating within controlled airspace. The clearances help ensure safe separation between aircraft under the jurisdiction of air traffic control, maintaining safety and efficiency in the airspace.
subject: Regulations

question: Clearances will be issued by an ATC unit for the purpose of:

choices.choice: Achieving separation between controlled flights
Providing alerting services
Providing advisory services

explanation:
Clearances are issued solely for expediting and separating air traffic and are based on known traffic conditions which affect safety in aircraft operation. The traffic conditions include:

  • aircraft in the air;
  • aircraft on the manoeuvring area;
  • vehicles on the manoeuvring area;
  • obstructions not permanently installed on the manoeuvring area.
subject: Regulations

question: You receive an IFR enroute clearance starting: Clearance expires at 0920. What does it mean?

choices.choice: If not airborne until 0920, a new clearance has to be issued
The take off clearance is expected at 0920
After 0920 return to the ramp and file a new flight plan

explanation:
If not airborne until 0920, a new clearance has to be issued.

This indicates that if the aircraft is not airborne by 0920, the issued clearance will no longer be valid. In such a case, the pilot must contact ATC to receive a new clearance or update their flight plan. It does not refer to the exact time of takeoff clearance nor the need to return to the ramp and file a new flight plan unless directed to do so by ATC.
subject: Regulations

question: ATIS broadcast

choices.choice: Shall only be transmitted on a discrete VHF frequency
Shall not be transmitted on the voice channel of an ILS
Shall not be transmitted on the voice of VOR

explanation:
Voice ATIS (Automatic Terminal Information Service) is typically broadcast on a discrete VHF frequency, which is usually displayed on aerodrome charts or approach plates. In some cases, it may also be transmitted via the voice channel of a VOR (VHF Omnidirectional Range), often linked to departure or arrival procedures.

However, it is important to note that ATIS is never transmitted on the voice channel of an Instrument Landing System (ILS), as the ILS voice channel is reserved for critical navigation information. The ATIS broadcast itself is continuous and repetitive, providing updated weather, runway, and operational information to pilots without requiring direct communication with ATC.
subject: Regulations

question: Whenever ATIS is provided, the preparation and dissemination of the ATIS message shall be the responsibility of

choices.choice: Both air traffic services and the meteorological office
The meteorological office serving the aerodromes
The air traffic services

explanation:
Automatic Terminal Information Service (ATIS) broadcasts, which include both Voice ATIS and Data ATIS, are indeed prepared and disseminated by Air Traffic Services (ATS).

While Voice ATIS provides continuous, repetitive broadcasts over VHF frequencies or sometimes via VOR channels, Data ATIS is delivered digitally, often via data link systems (like ACARS) to the aircraft.
subject: Regulations

question: Whenever ATIS is provided, the broadcast information shall be updated

choices.choice: As prescribed by the meteorological office
Immediately a significant change occurs
As prescribed by the state

explanation:
ATIS (Automatic Terminal Information Service) information typically pertains to a single aerodrome, delivering essential operational details like current weather, active runways, and other relevant data.

ATIS is updated immediately when any significant change occurs, such as changes in runway usage, weather conditions, or other critical updates, ensuring that pilots have the most current information before departure or arrival.
subject: Regulations

question: The ATIS broadcast message should, whenever practicable, not exceed

choices.choice: 30 seconds
1 minute
2 minutes

explanation:
The ATIS broadcast, which provides relevant information for a specific aerodrome, is expected to be brief (lasting no longer than 30 seconds) and updated immediately when a significant change occurs.

The ATS (Air Traffic Services) is responsible for ensuring that the ATIS service is continuously available and up to date.
subject: Regulations

question: ATIS broadcast messages containing departure and arrival information should include cloud cover, when the clouds are:

choices.choice: Below 900m (3000ft) or below the highest minimum sector altitude, whichever is the greater
Below 2000m (600ft) or below the highest minimum sector altitude whichever is the greater
Below 1500m (5000ft) or below the highest minimum sector altitude, whichever is the greater

explanation:
The ATIS (Automatic Terminal Information Service) broadcast will typically include information about cloud cover only under specific conditions:

  1. Cloud base is below 5,000 feet: If the base of the clouds is at or below 5,000 feet above the aerodrome elevation, the cloud cover will be included in the ATIS broadcast.
  2. Highest Minimum Safe Altitude (MSA): If the highest MSA for the area is higher than 5,000 feet, the ATIS will include cloud information when the cloud base is below that MSA.
  3. Presence of Cumulonimbus Clouds: Cumulonimbus clouds are significant due to their association with severe weather, so they will be reported regardless of their height.
subject: Regulations

question: When are ATIS broadcasts updated?

choices.choice: Upon receipt of any official weather, regardless of content change or reported values
Every 30 minutes if weather conditions are below those for VFR; otherwise hourly
Only when the ceiling and/or visibility changes by a reportable value

explanation:
Upon receipt of any official weather, regardless of content change or reported values.

This means that any time there is new official weather information, even if the values are unchanged, the ATIS broadcast will be updated to ensure pilots receive the most current information available.
subject: Regulations

question: Flight Information Service shall be provided to aircraft in order to avoid collision hazards when operating in airspace classes:

choices.choice: F and G only
C, D, E, F and G
A, B, C, D, E, F and G

explanation:
Flight Information is provided to all air traffic that is likely to be affected by
the information ., information is to be provided concerning:

• Weather conditions reported or forecast at departure, destination or alternate
aerodromes;
• Collision hazards to aircraft operating in classes C, D, E, F and G airspace;
• For flights over sea areas (when requested by pilots), details of surface vessels.
subject: Regulations

question: The lateral limit of CTR shall extend to atleast ________NMs from the center of aerodrome in directions from where approaches may be made:
explanation:
• Size and Coverage: A CTR is designed to provide sufficient airspace to deliver air traffic control services effectively. It typically extends at least 5 nautical miles (NM) from the aerodrome reference position in the direction from which approaches are made.
  • Integration with CTA: If the CTR is established within the lateral limits of a Control Area (CTA), it must extend upward to the lower limit of that CTA. This ensures seamless air traffic control services between different classes of airspace.
subject: Regulations

question: At radio communications, “Distress” differs from “Urgency” because in the first case

choices.choice: The aeroplane has suffered damages which impair its fitness to fly
There is a serious and imminent danger requiring immediate assistance
The aeroplane will not be able to reach a suitable aerodrome

explanation:
• Distress: This indicates that an aircraft or person is in a situation of grave and imminent danger and requires immediate assistance. It typically involves scenarios such as an engine failure, loss of control, or other situations that severely threaten the safety of the aircraft and its occupants.
  • Urgency: This term refers to situations that require timely attention but do not involve an immediate threat to life or the aircraft. For example, an aircraft might declare urgency if it has a technical issue that needs to be addressed but is not currently in a life-threatening situation.
subject: Regulations

question: The Alerting Service is provided by:

choices.choice: The Area Control Centers
The ATS unit responsible for the aircraft at that moment
Only by ATC units

explanation: Within an FIR, the provision of service to aircraft requesting assistance or indicating that they may require assistance is the responsibility of the Alerting Service of ATS. This service is provided by any ATS unit (ACC, ATCU, FIC etc…) regardless of the type of service normally offered. The Alerting Service is the link between the aircraft needing assistance, and the services that can provide that assistance. Where necessary, the provision of a service to aircraft in need of assistance will have priority over all other air traffic services.
subject: Regulations

question: The phases related to an aircraft in emergency or believed in emergency are:

choices.choice: Uncertainty phase, distress phase, urgency phase
Uncertainty phase, alert phase, distress phase
Uncertainty phase, urgency phase, distress phase

explanation:
The phases related to an aircraft in emergency or believed to be in emergency are typically classified into the following categories:

1. Distress Phase

  • This phase is declared when an aircraft is in serious and imminent danger and requires immediate assistance. It is often indicated by the transmission of a “Mayday” call.
  • Examples of situations that may lead to this phase include:
    • Critical system failures (e.g., loss of engine power)
    • Fuel exhaustion
    • Structural damage

2. Urgency Phase

  • This phase indicates that an aircraft is experiencing a potential problem that requires assistance but is not immediately life-threatening. It is usually signaled by a “Pan-Pan” call.
  • Situations that may trigger this phase include:
    • Navigational difficulties
    • Medical emergencies where immediate assistance is needed but the aircraft is still capable of flying

3. Alert Phase

  • This phase is declared when an aircraft is suspected to be in distress but has not yet communicated that it is in need of immediate assistance. This phase can be triggered by:
    • Failure to report at a designated reporting point
    • Loss of communication without a clear reason
    • Delayed landing or arrival times without prior notification

Key Considerations:

  • During these phases, air traffic controllers and relevant authorities will prioritize communication and assistance to the affected aircraft.
  • Coordination with search and rescue services may also be initiated, particularly during the distress and alert phases.
subject: Regulations

question: When an aircraft is experiencing difficulties, triggering of the alert phase is the responsibility of

choices.choice: Search and rescue coordination centers
Control centers only
Air traffic control and flight information centers

explanation: FICs and ACCs will serve as the central point for collecting all information relevant to an aircraft state of emergency and forwarding such information to the appropriate rescue co-ordination centre (RCC). If an emergency arises when an aircraft is under the control of the aerodrome or approach controller, that office will notify the ACC or FIC which in turn will notify the RCC.

question: Alert phase is defined as follows:

choices.choice: A situation where an apprehension exists as to the safety of an aircraft and its occupants
An emergency event in which an aircraft and its occupants are considered to be threatened by a danger
A situation related to an aircraft and its occupants are considered to be in a state of emergency

explanation:
Alert Phase (ALERFA)

The Alert Phase is declared when there is uncertainty about the safety of an aircraft and its occupants. It occurs under the following conditions:

  1. Communication Failure: Attempts to contact the aircraft have failed with no updates.
  2. Landing Clearance: The aircraft does not land within 5 minutes after clearance.
  3. Impaired Efficiency: The aircraft’s operational efficiency is compromised, but a forced landing is not imminent.
  4. Unlawful Interference: The aircraft is known to have experienced unlawful interference.
subject: Regulations

question: A situation in which apprehension exists as to the safety of an aircraft. To which emergency phase does this situation correcspond?

choices.choice: ALERFA
INCERFA
DETRESFA

explanation:
• Uncertainty Phase (INCERFA): a situation wherein uncertainty exists as to the safety of an aircraft and its occupants.
  • Alert Phase (ALERFA): a situation wherein apprehension exists as to the safety of an aircraft and its occupants.
  • Distress Phase (DETRESFA): a situation wherein there is reasonable certainty that an aircraft and its occupants are threatened by grave and imminent danger and require immediate assistance.
subject: Regulations

question: Which of the following signals is a distress signal?

choices.choice: In radiotelephony the spoken words PAN, PAN
A parachute flare showing a red light
The repeated switching on and off of the navigation lights

explanation:
The following signals, used either together or separately, mean that grave and imminent danger threatens, and immediate assistance is requested:

  • a signal made by radiotelegraphy or by any other signalling method consisting of the group SOS (. . . — — — . . . in the Morse Code)
  • a radio telephony distress signal consisting of the spoken word MAYDAY
  • a distress message sent via data link which transmits the intent of the word MAYDAY
  • rockets or shells throwing red lights, fired one at a time at short intervals
  • a parachute flare showing a red light
subject: Regulations

question: An aircraft is in emergency when:

choices.choice: It is threatened by grave danger
It is threatened by grave danger and requires immediate assistance
It is forced to land

explanation: A pilot will issue a distress call by using the words MAYDAY (3x) followed by his message when he is in a condition of being threatened by serious and/or imminent danger and of requiring immediate assistance.

question: The different emergency phases (in correct order) are:

explanation:
• Uncertainty Phase (INCERFA): a situation wherein uncertainty exists as to the safety of an aircraft and its occupants.
  • Alert Phase (ALERFA): a situation wherein apprehension exists as to the safety of an aircraft and its occupants.
  • Distress Phase (DETRESFA): a situation wherein there is reasonable certainty that an aircraft and its occupants are threatened by grave and imminent danger and require immediate assistance.

question: Which of the following statement describes the Alert Phase (ALERFA)?

choices.choice: An aircraft fails to arrive within 30 minutes of the ETA which was last notified to ATC.
An aircraft declares that the fuel remaining is insufficient to reach safety
An aircraft which has been cleared to land fails to land within 5 minutes of the ETA and communication has not been re-established.

explanation:
Alert Phase (ALERFA):
This phase is declared following the uncertainty phase when:

  • Communication attempts have failed, and there is no further news about the aircraft.
  • An aircraft fails to land within 5 minutes after receiving a landing clearance.
  • Information indicates that the aircraft’s operating efficiency is impaired, although a forced landing is not imminent.
  • The aircraft is known to have been subject to unlawful interference.
subject: Regulations

question: DETRESFA is where:

choices.choice: An aircraft fails to land within 5 minutes of being cleared to land
The fuel on board is considered to be exhausted
All answers are correct

explanation:
Distress Phase (DETRESFA):
This phase is declared after the alert phase, except when it is reasonably certain that the aircraft and its occupants are not in grave danger. It is initiated when:

  • Further communication attempts fail, and widespread inquiries suggest the aircraft is in distress.
  • The aircraft’s fuel is deemed exhausted.
  • The aircraft’s operating efficiency is impaired to the point that a forced landing is likely.
  • Information indicates that the aircraft is about to make or has made a forced landing.
subject: Regulations

question: RSP 180 Indicates:

Time in seconds between flight crew/HMI and controller/HMI.
Distance in NMs between two way points in defined RSP airspace.

RSP Required Surveillance Performance

RSP 180 sets the maximum time of 180 seconds for the total round-trip communication time, which includes surveillance data exchange between the aircraft and air traffic control.

question: A strayed aircraft is an aircraft:

that has been observed or is reported to be operating in a given area but whose identity has not been established.
only that aircraft which has deviated significantly its intended track.

explanation:
Strayed and Unidentified Aircraft. A strayed aircraft is one that has deviated

question: Having filed a flight plan to a particular destination and having landed at another destination, you should notify ATC:

choices.choice: within 60 minutes after landing at the alternate destination
within 30 minutes after landing at the alternate destination
within 30 minutes of your intended ETA at your original destination

explanation:
If an aircraft lands at a destination other than its intended destination, the pilot in command must report this to the appropriate air traffic services unit within 30 minutes of the estimated time of arrival (ETA) at the original destination, as part of ensuring that search and rescue services are not unnecessarily activated.

The Uncertainty phase (INCERFA) is declared when:

  • No communication has been received from an aircraft within 30 minutes of expected contact.
  • The aircraft fails to arrive within 30 minutes of the ETA.

This indicates initial concern for the aircraft’s safety, potentially escalating to more serious phases if no further information is obtained.
subject: Regulations

question: Designated airspace within controlled airspace in India is classified as Class:

choices.choice: C
D
C and D.

explanation:
Class C: Designated airspace within controlled airspace is classified as Class C. IFR and VFR flights are permitted, all flights are provided with air traffic control service and IFR flights are separated from other IFR flights and from VFR flights. VFR flights are separated from IFR flights and receive traffic information in respect of other VFR flights.

Class D: Airspace within controlled airspace is classified as Class D. IFR and VFR flights are permitted, and all flights are provided with air traffic control service, IFR flights are separated from other IFR flights and receive traffic information in respect of VFR flights, VFR flights receive traffic information in respect of all other flights.
subject: Regulations
